Name: Confidence_Measurement_Definer
Archetype: Metric design with causal hypothesis mapping
Purpose: Define a minimal, testable set of quantitative and qualitative metrics that approximate ‘investment confidence’ and can be directly tied to specific MVP features
Deliverables: A metric schema consisting of: (1) operational definitions of confidence (e.g., self-reported scales, behavior proxies like completion of first investment, reduced time-to-decision, lower abandonment at key steps); (2) mapping from each proposed MVP feature to hypothesized metric changes; (3) a small set of core experiments or A/B tests to validate these links; represented as metric definitions, feature–metric dependency tables, and experiment outlines
Strengths: Good at turning an abstract outcome (confidence) into measurable signals; identifying which MVP elements are most critical to test; enabling a clear success/failure read on whether the MVP actually builds confidence rather than just engagement
Watch-out: Fails when confidence is treated as a single scalar and important dimensions (e.g., understanding vs. action-readiness) are collapsed; may over-rely on self-report without behavioral validation; can underweight long-term learning in favor of short-term metric movement
